snippet: Sima Wali left Afghanistan 23 years ago when the Soviet Army swept into her country. Afghanistan was thrown into a downward spiral of violence, rivalry, civil war and harsh religious rule that finally forced Afghan women out of public life, jobs a...
lead_paragraph: Sima Wali left Afghanistan 23 years ago when the Soviet Army swept into her country. Afghanistan was thrown into a downward spiral of violence, rivalry, civil war and harsh religious rule that finally forced Afghan women out of public life, jobs and education. ''In these 23 years, Afghan women have had to fight their own jihad for peace and equality,'' Ms. Wali said. ''It was a jihad, really. But it has also politicized Afghan women, even from behind the veil.''
abstract: Three women are taking part as delegates in United Nations talks in Bonn on provisional government for post-Taliban Afghanistan; they are Sima Wali, who left Afghanistan 23 years ago, Rona Mansuri, who left in 1960's, and Amena Safi Afzali, exile now living in Iran and representing Northern Alliance; they are pressing for resumption of rights for women taken away during Taliban regime; photo (M)

headline.main: In Bonn, Three Champions for Afghan Women

snippet: A fundamental disagreement over whether the Constitution and civil rights laws are ''color-blind,'' as the Reagan Administration contends, runs through the increasingly bitter disputes between the   Administration and most major civil rights group...
lead_paragraph: A fundamental disagreement over whether the Constitution and civil rights laws are ''color-blind,'' as the Reagan Administration contends, runs through the increasingly bitter disputes between the Administration and most major civil rights groups. This disagreement underlies radically different approaches to important civil rights issues, in particular the Administration's opposition to hiring quotas based on race and sex to overcome job discrimination and mandatory busing to end school segregation. The Administration's positions on these issues reflect its rejection of a principle embodied in many Federal court decisions: that special preferences for blacks and other disadvantaged groups, and special ''race-conscious'' efforts to integrate schools, are necessary in some cases to avoid perpetuating the effects of past discrimination. William Bradford Reynolds, head of the Justice Department's civil rights division, justified the Administration's opposition to such race-conscious civil rights policies in a recent speech by invoking ''the color-blind ideal of equal opportunity for all.''

lead_paragraph: A sampling of the smashed lives in this city's first shelter for battered women shows just how much work its founder, Yanar Mohamed, has before her. There is Susan, whose new husband began to beat her after discovering that she had been raped as a teenager. He held their new baby to her breast for feedings, because she was not allowed to touch the infant. She now lives in the shelter with the child.
abstract: Yanar Mohamed, Iraqi-Canadian rights advocate, opens first shelter for battered women in Baghdad, and another in Kirkuk; women come without papers or passports because in punishing and rigid Islamic tradition, some would be killed if relatives found them; women in Iraq began losing their rights in 1980's, when years of war sapped economic resources, plunging country into poverty and eroding women's independence; Sadam Hussein, to appease religious leaders, forced stricter adherence to conservative religious rules; killing and abuse of women stretches across class and educational lines; photo (M)

snippet: In its term that ended last week, a deeply divided Supreme Court granted new constitutional rights to illegal aliens, retarded people in state institutions and public school students fighting the politically motivated removal of books from school ...
lead_paragraph: In its term that ended last week, a deeply divided Supreme Court granted new constitutional rights to illegal aliens, retarded people in state institutions and public school students fighting the politically motivated removal of books from school libaries. At the same time, the Court made it more difficult to seek some rights in the Federal courts. It placed new barriers in the path of prisoners seeking to challenge their convictions in Federal court and giving government officials new protection against suits by citizens whose rights they may have violated. Many of the Court's most important rulings this year seemed more the product of fragile and shifting coalitions among the Justices than of any overriding vision of the law or the Constitution. Among the numerous 5-to-4 decisions were those holding that the President of the United States is absolutely immune from civil suit for illegal or unconstitutional acts taken in his term, that illegal alien children are entitled to a free public education, that male students may not be barred from a state-operated school of nursing and that the Constitution limits the discretion of school boards to remove books from library shelves.

snippet: The United States Commission on Civil Rights has reorganized its 50 state advisory committees, appointing more white men to head them.   Civil rights groups have complained that the new committees, which monitor and report on developments in their...
lead_paragraph: The United States Commission on Civil Rights has reorganized its 50 state advisory committees, appointing more white men to head them. Civil rights groups have complained that the new committees, which monitor and report on developments in their states, will be more conservative than the old committees and more likely to abandon their role as advocates for racial minorities and women. But a White House official said that many of the new appointees are prominent in the field of civil rights and that such fears are unfounded. Under Federal law, the advisory committees are rechartered every two years, which allows the White House to change the number and composition of their members. According to statistics released this week by commission officials, there are 313 new appointees among the more than 500 members of the new advisory panels. Men head 46 of the panels and women head 4, as against 31 men and 20 women as chairmen of the old panels. Figures for the previous committees include the one for the District of Columbia, whose rechartering is incomplete.

headline.main: STATE RIGHTS PANELS ARE BEING HEADED BY MORE WHITE MEN

snippet: A new report from the United States Commission on Civil Rights unequivocally rejects the proposition that men and women should be paid the same for different jobs of comparable worth.    The 232-page study concluded that ''comparable worth, as a t...
lead_paragraph: A new report from the United States Commission on Civil Rights unequivocally rejects the proposition that men and women should be paid the same for different jobs of comparable worth. The 232-page study concluded that ''comparable worth, as a theory of discrimination or as a remedy for discrimination, is profoundly and irretrievably flawed.'' Under a policy of comparable worth, employers assess the intrinsic value of different jobs by measuring such factors as the knowledge, skills and effort required of employees, their degree of responsibility and their working conditions.

headline.main: IDEA OF JOB WORTH IS CALLED 'FLAWED'

snippet: The Center for Individual Rights, a nonprofit conservative law firm, is fast developing an unusual niche: challenging colleges and universities on behalf of those who regard themselves as victims of political correctness.   The center, founded in ...
lead_paragraph: The Center for Individual Rights, a nonprofit conservative law firm, is fast developing an unusual niche: challenging colleges and universities on behalf of those who regard themselves as victims of political correctness. The center, founded in 1989, has gained prominence by winning high-profile cases like Ronald Rosenberger's against the University of Virginia. In a 5-to-4 decision in June, the Supreme Court held that the university was required to provide student-activity financing for a student-run religious magazine.

snippet: After impassioned debate, the United States Commission on Civil Rights today urged Congress and Government agencies to reject the doctrine that men and women should be paid the same for different jobs of comparable worth.     The vote was 5 to 2. ...
lead_paragraph: After impassioned debate, the United States Commission on Civil Rights today urged Congress and Government agencies to reject the doctrine that men and women should be paid the same for different jobs of comparable worth. The vote was 5 to 2. One member, Francis S. Guess, the Tennessee State Commissioner of Labor, abstained. Voting with the majority, Morris B. Abram, vice chairman of the commission, said: ''There is sex-based discrimination in America, but it is declining. The repetitious charge that women earn only 60 percent of what men earn in this country obscures the significant fact that women work less hours, have less seniority and work more intermittently.''

headline.main: U. S. PANEL ON CIVIL RIGHTS REJECTS PAY-EQUITY THEORY

snippet: To the Editor:    In ''A Selection No Longer Unthinkable'' (Metro Matters, May 18), Joyce Purnick makes much of Harold O. Levy's being ''a Jewish white man'' as if to herald a new era of ''merit'' for the post of schools chancellor. This thesis is...
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In ''A Selection No Longer Unthinkable'' (Metro Matters, May 18), Joyce Purnick makes much of Harold O. Levy's being ''a Jewish white man'' as if to herald a new era of ''merit'' for the post of schools chancellor. This thesis is condescending to former minority chancellors.

snippet: Injunctions against antisocial behavior are increasingly popular. And troubling....
lead_paragraph: Nineteen-year-old Kerry McLaughlin has received more than 100 complaints about the loud parties she has held in her apartment near Newcastle, England, over the past 18 months. It has been said that she invites 10-year-olds to get drunk, smashes windows and heaves trash cans at cars. But it was only after she roped a male acquaintance naked to a nearby lamppost and left him there that British tabloids started calling her an ''ASBO queen.'' ASBO is an acronym for the ''anti-social behavior orders'' that have been introduced by the government of Prime Minister Tony Blair. He has promised to extend them in the third term he won in elections earlier this month. An ASBO is a kind of esoteric injunction that bans people from highly specific acts that fall just this side of criminality. Kerry McLaughlin's order, for instance, threatened her with jail if she had more than two guests over after 10 at night.

headline.main: There Ought To Be a Law?

snippet: Following a ruling by a state agency that Princeton University's three all-male eating clubs unlawfully discriminate against women, those involved in the case are preparing for a lengthy legal battle and assessing the decision's implications.   Th...
lead_paragraph: Following a ruling by a state agency that Princeton University's three all-male eating clubs unlawfully discriminate against women, those involved in the case are preparing for a lengthy legal battle and assessing the decision's implications. The New Jersey Division of Civil Rights ruled this week that the clubs' ties to the university render them public accommodations and therefore subject to the same law concerning discrimination as the university. The decision came in a five-year-old complaint by Sally Frank, a 1980 Princeton graduate whose requests to join the eating clubs were rejected in 1979. The decision, which established state jurisdiction over the clubs, is not binding, but will probably result in an order by the division for the clubs to consider women for admission, according to the participants. Such an order could be appealed to the courts, however.

snippet: Richard Riley arrived at Kennedy International Airport two years ago a carefree college freshman, just back from a Christmas break visit with his mother in Jamaica. He left the airport 12 hours later shackled, accused of trying to enter the countr...
lead_paragraph: Richard Riley arrived at Kennedy International Airport two years ago a carefree college freshman, just back from a Christmas break visit with his mother in Jamaica. He left the airport 12 hours later shackled, accused of trying to enter the country with falsified documents. Mr. Riley, who was then and is now a legal resident of the United States, said immigration inspectors rejected his proof of residency, strip-searched him twice and kept him shackled to a bench in a busy airport office overnight.
abstract: Study released by Lawyers Committee for Human Rights finds that INS inspectors, with sweeping personal discretion to deport illegal immigrants, have mistreated or turned away legal visitors as well as victims of torture who had credible claims for political asylum; case of Jamaican student Richard Riley discussed (M)

snippet: There were 10 people traveling with the international human rights delegation, several of them Americans who looked extremely gringo and spoke no Spanish. They were in a Dodge Ram van that was almost as big as a city bus, and so it seemed a safe b...
lead_paragraph: There were 10 people traveling with the international human rights delegation, several of them Americans who looked extremely gringo and spoke no Spanish. They were in a Dodge Ram van that was almost as big as a city bus, and so it seemed a safe bet that their plan to sneak into the state mental hospital in Hidalgo was preposterous. Their hope was to document conditions at this mental institution, considered one of Mexico's snake pits, before the hospital director discovered what they were up to. They had one thing in their favor. Guiding the international entourage that chilly fall morning was Virginia Gonzalez, the Dorothea Dix of Mexico, that nation's leading advocate for the mentally ill and the country's No. 1 expert on sneaking into mental hospitals. In the previous decade, Virginia Gonzalez had wormed her way into most of the public mental institutions around Mexico, spending three nights posing as a patient at a women's hospital and smuggling a Mexico City mayor into a men's hospital late one night to view horrid conditions there.
abstract: Michael Winerip article on drive by Mental Disability Rights International for humane treatment of mentally ill worldwide; describes site visit by group to one of Mexico's decrepit mental hospitals; group seeks to add nation's treatment of mentally disabled to list of human rights; was founded by Eric Rosenthal and is financed by George Soros's Open Society Institute; photos (L)
